study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between postoperative leg length/offset reconstruction and gait performance after total hip arthroplasty.
results_summary: Combined limb length and offset restoration within 5mm resulted in improved gait performance (higher Froude number, normalized walking speed, and hip range-of-motion) one year postoperatively, though gait symmetry and clinical scores were unaffected by reconstruction accuracy.
population_specificity: 60 patients with unilateral hip arthrosis who underwent total hip arthroplasty.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the effects of eye patching on healing and pain relief for corneal abrasions, not walking.
results_summary: The study found that eye patching did not significantly improve healing or reduce pain for corneal abrasions compared to no patching. Walking was mentioned only in the context of daily activities, where wearing an eye patch made walking more difficult for children.
population_specificity: Participants with simple corneal abrasions (total of 1080 across 12 trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of exercise, including walking, on cognitive function in individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The review found conflicting evidence for the effects of exercise on cognition in MS, with overall positive but not definitive evidence for physical activity and physical fitness. Promising evidence from lower-quality studies suggests potential benefits, but methodological limitations prevent definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (MS), excluding pediatric-onset MS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of riociguat in improving walking distance (6MWD) and other clinical outcomes in patients with PAH associated with connective tissue disease (PAH-CTD).
results_summary: Riociguat improved mean 6-minute walking distance (6MWD), WHO functional class, pulmonary vascular resistance, and cardiac index in PAH-CTD patients, with sustained improvements at 2 years. The safety profile was similar to the overall population, and 2-year survival was high (93%).
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with connective tissue disease (PAH-CTD), including systemic sclerosis and other defined CTDs.
effective_dosage: Maximum 2.5 mg or 1.5 mg three times daily (PATENT-1); maximum 2.5 mg three times daily (PATENT-2).
study_duration: 12 weeks (PATENT-1), followed by long-term extension (PATENT-2) up to 2 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether statin therapy improves 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) and other indices in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no statistically significant improvement in 6MWD or other measured indices (pulmonary arterial pressure, right atrial pressure, cardiac index, pulmonary vascular resistance) with statin therapy. The results were consistent across multiple studies.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) (665 participants across 8 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess how different footwear conditions (regular shoe gear, surgical shoe, and walking boot) affect driving performance, specifically brake response times and accuracy.
results_summary: The study found that both surgical shoes and walking boots significantly slowed mean brake response times and increased abnormally delayed responses compared to regular shoes. Walking boots also led to more inaccurate brake responses, while surgical shoes did not show a significant difference in accuracy.
population_specificity: 25 participants without active right-sided lower extremity pathology.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (footwear conditions were compared, not dosages).

study_goal: The researchers sought to compare clinical characteristics, hemodynamics, and treatment responses in patients with pulmonary hypertension (PH) related to heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) or idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension (IPAH).
results_summary: Patients with PH-HFpEF and atypical IPAH showed improvements in exercise capacity (including 6-minute walking distance), functional class, and natriuretic peptides after PH-targeted therapy, though effects were less pronounced in PH-HFpEF compared to typical IPAH. Survival rates were similar across groups.
population_specificity: Patients with PH-HFpEF (n=226), typical IPAH (<3 left heart disease risk factors; n=421), and atypical IPAH (≥3 left heart disease risk factors; n=139).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a structured moderate-intensity walking program could reduce cardiovascular disease events in sedentary older adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant reduction in cardiovascular events among participants in the walking program compared to the control group, though a modest benefit was observed in frailer participants with lower physical performance scores.
population_specificity: Sedentary men and women aged 70-89 years with limited physical performance but able to walk 400 meters.
effective_dosage: Walking 2 times per week on-site (moderate intensity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of an educational intervention on improving health professionals' knowledge and practices regarding leisure-time walking and healthy eating during pregnancy.
results_summary: The intervention significantly improved professionals' knowledge about leisure-time walking (92% increase in score) and increased the likelihood of pregnant women receiving guidance on walking (PR = 2.65) compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Health professionals (doctors and nurses) providing primary care to pregnant women in São Paulo State, Brazil.
study_duration: 16 hours of training (introductory course and three workshops), with follow-up assessments 1 year post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the neurobiological underpinnings of walking impairment and discuss imaging approaches for diagnosing gait and balance disorders.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the neurologic structures involved in walking and balance, emphasizing the importance of imaging for diagnosis, but does not report specific outcomes or effects of walking itself.
population_specificity: Not specified (focuses on neurologic disorders affecting gait and balance).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of resistance exercise, alone or combined with aerobic training, on clinical outcomes in heart failure patients.
results_summary: The study found that resistance or combined training improved peak VO2, quality of life, and walking performance (six-minute walk distance) in heart failure patients, though mortality, hospitalization, blood pressure, and left ventricular fraction remained unchanged.
population_specificity: People with heart failure

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of three different treadmill training (TT) frequencies on gait performance in Parkinson's disease (PD) patients.
results_summary: Low-frequency (2-times/week) and intermediate-frequency (3-times/week) TT improved gait performance and reduced falls risk immediately post-training, with effects lasting up to 2 months. High-frequency (5-times/week) TT showed no improvement and worsened some outcomes at 4 months.
population_specificity: Thirty outpatients with Parkinson's disease.
effective_dosage: Ten sessions of 45 minutes each, with frequencies of 2, 3, or 5 times per week.
study_duration: Training duration was not explicitly stated, but follow-up evaluations occurred up to 4 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare clinical outcomes (pain, hip function, and walking ability) between two-stage and single-stage revision surgeries using PROSTALAC implants for periprosthetic joint infection after hip arthroplasty.
results_summary: The study found that two-stage revision (Group A) had significantly better pain and hip function scores than single-stage revision (Group B), but walking ability did not differ significantly between the groups. The infection resolution rate was high (94.9% final rate) for both approaches.
population_specificity: Patients who developed periprosthetic joint infection after primary hip arthroplasty, divided into two groups (two-stage vs. single-stage revision).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of the eHealth intervention 'MyPlan1.0' in increasing physical activity, including walking, among recently retired adults.
results_summary: The intervention significantly increased walking for transport and leisure-time walking in the short-term (1 week) and intermediate-term (1 month), with notable improvements compared to the control group. Other forms of physical activity, such as vigorous PA and gardening, also showed positive effects.
population_specificity: Recently retired Belgian adults (240 participants, aged not specified).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved self-regulation strategies via 'MyPlan1.0').
study_duration: 1 month (with follow-ups at 1 week and 1 month).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical outcomes of the conventional intramedullary hip screw (IMHS) and the redesigned Asian IMHS for treating trochanteric fractures of the femur.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in clinical parameters between the two IMHS groups, but the Asian IMHS had complications (intraoperative fractures in 3 patients and implant breakage in 1), while the conventional IMHS had none. The Asian IMHS was deemed better suited for Japanese patients due to its size and angle variations, provided careful intraoperative attention and appropriate nail selection.
population_specificity: 42 patients (21 per group) with trochanteric fractures of the femur, predominantly female (17 in Asian IMHS, 16 in conventional IMHS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify suitable efficacy endpoints and surrogates for pediatric pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) trials, given the lack of developmentally appropriate measures.
results_summary: The study found that the 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) was commonly used in adult PAH trials but unsuitable for infants and young children. Alternative surrogates like pulmonary vascular resistance index or mean pulmonary artery pressure were considered but posed high risks, and no fully validated noninvasive markers were identified.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of progressive resistance and balance exercises combined with motivational group discussions on physical and psychological functions in post-stroke individuals.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in balance and comfortable walking speed at 3 months, with the walking speed improvement persisting at 6 months. No differences were found for other outcomes like physical activity levels, quality of life, depression, or fall-related self-efficacy.
population_specificity: Community-living individuals aged 65-85 years who had a stroke 1-3 years prior (76% male).
effective_dosage: PRB exercises combined with motivational group discussions twice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if menu labels, including exercise labels showing minutes of brisk walking needed to burn food calories, influenced food choices in Hispanics.
results_summary: Menu labels (including walking-based exercise labels) did not significantly affect calories or macronutrients ordered. Label use was low (~26%), and calories ordered were similar regardless of label use. Factors like weight perception and health-based food selection influenced calorie intake more than labels.
population_specificity: 372 Hispanic adults aged 18-65 years.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on menu labels, not walking dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relative contribution of exercise alone (specifically walking) to improving glucose homeostasis in prediabetic individuals, comparing moderate- and vigorous-intensity exercise, and assessing the impact of exercise amount.
results_summary: The study found that a high amount of moderate-intensity walking (equivalent to ~22.3 km per week) significantly improved glucose tolerance, nearly matching the effectiveness of a combined diet and exercise intervention. Vigorous-intensity exercise alone did not show significant improvements in glucose tolerance.
population_specificity: Sedentary, non-smoking adults aged 45-75 with elevated fasting glucose but without cardiovascular disease, uncontrolled hypertension, or diabetes.
effective_dosage: 42 kJ/kg body weight/week (~16 km/week) or 67 kJ/kg body weight/week (~22.3 km/week), performed at moderate (50% VO2max) or vigorous (75% VO2max) intensity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate how different social network-based interventions (weekly tips, online fitness walking, and online networking) influenced moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) in inactive adults.
results_summary: Participants increased MVPA by 21.0 min/week at 3 months, sustained at 9 months, with no significant differences between intervention groups. The study concluded that varying social network procedures had similar functional effects on physical activity.
population_specificity: Physically inactive adults (n=308, mean age 50.3 years, 38.3% male, 83.4% overweight/obese).
effective_dosage: Not specified (interventions included weekly emailed tips, online fitness walking, and online networking prompts).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify risk factors for incident disability in activities of daily living (ADL) among middle-aged and older women and determine if these factors differ by age group.
results_summary: The study found that decreased grip strength and pain were significant risk factors for ADL disability in women aged 40-64, while decreased rapid walking speed, comorbidities, and pain were associated with ADL disability in women aged 65+.
population_specificity: 264 Japanese women aged 40 and older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the analgesic efficacy of ultrasound therapy and shock wave therapy in patients with heel spur.
results_summary: Both ultrasound and shock wave therapy reduced pain, with the largest decrease occurring within the first week of treatment. Shock wave therapy required fewer sessions than ultrasound therapy to achieve a similar analgesic effect.
population_specificity: 47 patients (both sexes, aged 38-60 years) with plantar calcaneal spur confirmed by X-ray.
effective_dosage: Group 1: 10 ultrasound therapy sessions; Group 2: 4-5 shock wave therapy sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dedicated follow-up and treatment of postoperative effusions improved recovery, measured by walking distance, in cardiac surgery patients.
results_summary: The study found that supplemental follow-up and treatment of effusions improved walking distance by 15% compared to standard care, with a more pronounced improvement (22%) in patients who underwent thoracentesis. No significant differences were observed in peak expiratory flow or EuroQOL.
population_specificity: Patients scheduled for elective on-pump coronary artery bypass grafting and/or aortic valve replacement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare quality of life, physical activity levels (including walking), and other factors between persons with dementia living in nursing homes versus those living at home.
results_summary: Home-dwelling persons with dementia showed higher quality of life, more physical activity (including less use of walking aids), and greater exposure to daylight compared to those in nursing homes. Residency (home vs. nursing home) significantly predicted quality of life and its decline over time.
population_specificity: Persons with dementia (moderate severity), including both nursing home residents and home-dwelling individuals.
study_duration: Not specified (cross-sectional baseline data with some follow-up)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether walking shoes with modified midsoles designed to unload the medial knee provided additional benefits in alleviating knee osteoarthritis symptoms compared to conventional walking shoes.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in pain or function between the intervention and control groups at 6 months, with both groups showing clinically relevant improvements. Unloading shoes did not increase the probability of improvement in pain or function compared to conventional shoes.
population_specificity: 164 persons with medial knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Daily wear of walking shoes (intervention: triple-density, variable-stiffness midsoles with mild lateral-wedge insoles; comparator: conventional walking shoes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the short-term efficacy of rigid versus soft lateral wedge arch support (LWAS) insoles for improving pain, physical activity, and quality of life in patients with knee osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: Patients using soft LWAS insoles showed significant improvements in pain, stair ascent time, daily living function, sports and recreation function, and quality of life compared to those using rigid LWAS insoles. The improvements were observed across multiple ICF components, including body functions and structures and activities and participation.
population_specificity: 90 participants (70 women, 20 men) with knee OA, mean ages 60.6 ± 10.8 (rigid group) and 63.1 ± 10.8 (soft group).
effective_dosage: 1 pair of rigid or soft LWAS insoles (specific frequency not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether programmed sports therapy (PST) could enhance physical work capacity, including walking performance, in patients with haemophilia.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in muscle strength, coordination, and walking distance (Δ+171.5 m in the 12-min walking test) in the intervention group compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate to severe haemophilia A and B (n=64).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the attributes, nurse involvement, and efficacy of community-based physical activity (PA) interventions, including walking, in promoting PA behavior change.
results_summary: Group-based interventions (e.g., exercise classes, group walking) were more effective in increasing PA compared to individual-based education, though less than half of the studies demonstrated efficacy. Multi-dose, face-to-face, group-based interventions lasting 6 months or less were the most common delivery modes.
population_specificity: 2,353 participants across 13 national and international studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate factors related to myelopathy deterioration caused by thoracic ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament (T-OPLL), including the role of walking ability as part of the assessment criteria.
results_summary: The study found that age, weight, BMI, discontinuity between OPLL lesions, and high-intensity areas on MRI were associated with myelopathy development. Walking ability (unaided or with support) was used to classify patients but was not a primary outcome measure.
population_specificity: Patients with thoracic myelopathy due to ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament (T-OPLL), including those with mild or no myelopathy (able to walk unaided or with support).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of bisoprolol on right ventricular ejection fraction (RVEF) and other functional parameters in patients with idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension (iPAH).
results_summary: Bisoprolol reduced heart rate but did not improve RVEF. It was associated with a decreased cardiac index and a trend toward reduced 6-minute walking distance, suggesting worsened cardiac function.
population_specificity: Patients with optimally treated, stable idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension (NYHA functional class II/III).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether slow loaded sit-to-stand exercises improve the physiological cost of walking in children with spastic diplegia compared to self-paced exercises.
results_summary: The study found that slow loaded sit-to-stand exercises significantly improved 6-minute walk distance (6MWD) and Physiological Cost Index (PCI) in children with cerebral palsy, suggesting reduced physiological cost of walking. The self-paced group did not show the same improvements.
population_specificity: Children aged 12-18 years with spastic diplegia cerebral palsy.
effective_dosage: 15 minutes, 4 sets per day, 3-4 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of a 12-week walking intervention for increasing physical activity in adults with intellectual disabilities.
results_summary: The intervention did not significantly increase physical activity levels, but the process evaluation identified key considerations for future studies, including recruitment strategies, intervention methods, and the role of carers.
population_specificity: Adults with intellectual disabilities
effective_dosage: Not specified (pedometer use encouraged for goal setting and monitoring)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify pre- and postsurgical factors predictive of chronic postsurgical pain (CPSP) 6 months after knee replacement, with a focus on walking ability as a key factor.
results_summary: The study found that preoperative factors like limited walking ability and lack of physical activity, as well as high-intensity acute postoperative pain, were associated with CPSP. Patients with high-intensity postoperative pain had higher anxiety levels and worse preoperative walking ability.
population_specificity: Patients referred for total or unicompartmental knee arthroplasty at a French orthopedic hospital.
study_duration: Follow-up at 3 and 6 months after surgery

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the reported patient experience and variation in limb fitting services after amputation for musculoskeletal tumours in England.
results_summary: The study found significant variation in limb fitting services, with many patients reporting care falling short of national standards in areas like pre-amputation counselling, psychological support, and falls management. Patients seen at centres with on-site limb fitting services experienced better care and were seen sooner.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent amputation for musculoskeletal tumours in England.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the costs and effectiveness of treatments for lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD), including walking (exercise), in low- and middle-income countries.
results_summary: Exercise was found to be more effective and cost-effective for improving walking distance in PAD patients compared to pharmacotherapy, and it was prioritized over resource-intensive treatments like revascularization in low-resource settings.
population_specificity: Patients with lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD) in low- and middle-income countries.

study_goal: The study aimed to describe the phenotypic expression and survival of ATTR amyloidosis in the U.S., focusing on Val122Ile and wild-type ATTR, including neurologic symptoms like walking disability.
results_summary: The study found that Val122Ile patients had a greater burden of neurologic symptoms, including walking disability, compared to wild-type ATTR, but survival rates did not differ between the groups.
population_specificity: Older adult male subjects in the U.S., predominantly of African descent, with ATTR amyloidosis (Val122Ile or wild-type).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility, safety, and preliminary efficacy of an individually tailored home- and community-based exercise program to improve cardiorespiratory fitness and walking capacity in stroke survivors.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in cardiorespiratory fitness (VO2peak) and walking distance compared to the control group, with no adverse events reported. The improvements were comparable to those seen in supervised, center-based programs.
population_specificity: Independently ambulant, community-dwelling stroke survivors.
effective_dosage: Individually tailored exercise program with once-weekly telephone or e-mail support.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term efficacy and safety of elosulfase alfa enzyme replacement therapy in Morquio A patients, focusing on improvements in walking endurance and other functional measures.
results_summary: The study found sustained improvements in the six-minute walk test (6MWT) and three-minute stair climb test (3MSCT) over 120 weeks, with significant differences compared to untreated natural history study patients. Normalized urine keratan sulfate (uKS) levels also showed sustained reductions, indicating biochemical efficacy.
population_specificity: Morquio A patients (N=173 ITT, N=124 MPP).
effective_dosage: 2.0mg/kg/week (established as the recommended dose during the study).
study_duration: 120 weeks (including a 24-week placebo-controlled phase and a 96-week extension).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of moderate (brisk walking) and vigorous-moderate exercise on intrahepatic triglyceride content and metabolic risk factors in patients with NAFLD.
results_summary: Both vigorous-moderate and moderate exercise (brisk walking) significantly reduced intrahepatic triglyceride content, body weight, waist circumference, and blood pressure, with effects largely mediated by weight loss. No significant difference was found between the two exercise intensities in reducing liver fat.
population_specificity: Adults with central obesity and NAFLD, predominantly women (67.7%), mean age 53.9 years.
effective_dosage: Brisk walking 150 minutes per week at 45%-55% of maximum heart rate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of combination therapy (CT) versus monotherapy (MT) with pulmonary vasodilators in reducing clinical worsening events and improving physiological outcomes in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).
results_summary: CT significantly reduced the risk of combined clinical worsening events by 38%, improved 6-minute walking distance by 23.0 meters, enhanced functional class, and had beneficial effects on pulmonary hemodynamics, though it did not significantly reduce mortality.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare clinical outcomes between osteosynthesis and endoprosthesis for femoral neck fractures in elderly Asian patients and analyze factors affecting osteosynthesis failure.
results_summary: In non-displaced fractures, bipolar hemiarthroplasty (BPHA) had fewer complications than internal fixation (IF), but no significant differences in re-operation rates or walking ability degradation. For displaced fractures, BPHA outperformed IF in complications, re-operation rates, and walking ability. Osteoporosis did not significantly affect non-union rates.
population_specificity: Elderly Asian patients (65+ years) with femoral neck fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify, compare, and discuss the predictive capacity of existing equations for the 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) in obese subjects.
results_summary: The study found that none of the existing equations accurately predicted the 6MWD in obese subjects, suggesting that other unaccounted factors influence walking performance in this population. The complexity of disability in obese individuals may not be fully captured by current predictive models.
population_specificity: Obese subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the functional performance of the automatic stance-phase lock (ASPL) knee mechanism against the weight-activated braking (WAB) prosthetic knee joint in individuals with above-knee amputations.
results_summary: The study found no difference in walking speeds between the two knee mechanisms, but the ASPL knee showed lower energy expenditure (PCI). Participants preferred the ASPL knee for stability and improved walking, though some noted terminal impact noise as a limitation. Nine of ten participants chose to continue using the ASPL knee long-term.
population_specificity: 10 young adults with above-knee amputations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a motor adaptation protocol versus a therapeutic exercise protocol on mobility and postural balance in individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: Both treatment groups showed statistically significant improvements in postural balance, walking endurance, walking speed, and step length, but there were no significant differences between the two protocols. The study suggests that high-frequency physical therapy, rather than a specific activity focus, may be key for improving mobility in MS patients.
population_specificity: Individuals with relapsing-remitting or secondary progressive MS (EDSS scores 3.0-6.5).
effective_dosage: Therapy sessions twice daily, 5 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the real-life efficacy and safety of fampridine for improving gait disorders in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: Fampridine improved walking speed by 20% or more in 70% of patients, while 8% reported mild or moderate adverse events. Improvement in walking speed was independent of disability level.
population_specificity: Patients with MS and gait disorders, regardless of disability level.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate gender-related data and the genetic influence on idiopathic toe walking (ITW) in children.
results_summary: The study found that 64% of toe-walkers were boys, 42% had a positive family history (PF-TW), and 60% of PF-TW children had fathers with a toe-walking pattern. PF-TW children were more severely affected in clinical tests and were on average half a year younger than NF-TW children.
population_specificity: 836 children with idiopathic toe walking (ITW).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of two social cognitive theory-based interventions in increasing walking and compare their efficacy between dog owners and non-dog owners.
results_summary: Both intervention groups showed greater increases in walking at 6 months, which were maintained at 12 months, with the highest increases observed in the dog owner intervention group. The study concluded that dog owners accumulated more walking, potentially due to the dog-owner relationship.
population_specificity: Adult dog owners (n = 40) and non-dog owners (n = 65).
effective_dosage: Bi-weekly emails for the first 4 weeks, then weekly emails for the next 8 weeks.
study_duration: 12 months (intervention lasted 12 weeks, with follow-up at 6 and 12 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a minimally invasive paraspinal approach for treating spontaneous spinal epidural hematoma (SSEH) and its impact on restoring walking ability.
results_summary: The study found that the minimally invasive approach successfully treated SSEH, with the patient regaining the ability to walk with a cane after three months and showing normal to near-normal muscle strength in the lower limbs, with no reported complications.
population_specificity: An 81-year-old woman with spontaneous spinal epidural hematoma (SSEH) causing lower limb weakness and difficulty walking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current knowledge on how multiple sclerosis affects gait mechanics and explore the potential of 3D gait analysis as a marker of disease progression.
results_summary: The study found that ankle joint functionality is most affected during walking in PwMS, with compensatory actions often insufficient to maintain speed. Altered gait patterns may serve as a stability strategy due to balance impairments.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (PwMS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the "Camminando e leggendo… ricordo" (CLR) model, which combines walking and reading activities, as a secondary prevention strategy for Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) in older adults.
results_summary: The study proposed a protocol to assess the CLR model's impact on promoting healthy lifestyles and reducing dementia risk, using multidimensional geriatric assessments, frailty detection, and quality-of-life measures, but specific results on walking's effects were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Older adults with Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term effectiveness and safety of the ActiGait implantable drop foot stimulator in improving gait speed, endurance, and quality of life in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS)-related drop foot.
results_summary: The ActiGait stimulator significantly improved gait speed by 23.6% at 10 weeks and 36.3% at 1 year, increased walking endurance from 217 m to 321 m, and enhanced mobility, social participation, and quality of life. Results remained stable over the 1-year follow-up period.
population_specificity: Six patients with MS and 2 years of persisting central leg paresis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate why some individuals at high risk of type 2 diabetes fail to improve insulin sensitivity after physical training interventions involving cycling and walking.
results_summary: The study found that nonresponders to insulin sensitivity improvement after training exhibited impaired upregulation of mitochondrial fuel oxidation genes and suppression of regulators like PGC1α and AMPKα2, linked to increased TGF-β activity in skeletal muscle. This suggests TGF-β signaling may hinder mitochondrial and insulin sensitivity improvements post-exercise.
population_specificity: Middle-aged individuals at high risk of developing type 2 diabetes.
effective_dosage: Training at 80% individual Vo2 peak (specific frequency not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the effects of opioids compared to placebo for treating restless legs syndrome (RLS) in adults, not specifically evaluating walking.
results_summary: The study found that opioids improved RLS symptoms, quality of life, and sleep quality compared to placebo, but with more adverse events in the drug group. Walking was mentioned as a movement that alleviates RLS symptoms but was not the focus of the study.
population_specificity: Adults with idiopathic restless legs syndrome.
effective_dosage: Prolonged-release oxycodone/naloxone (specific dosage not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between spatiotemporal gait parameters, balance performance, and falls history in ambulant adults with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found that faster gait speed was associated with better balance performance, and individuals with a history of falls had significantly shorter stride lengths. These results suggest potential therapeutic targets for improving gait speed or balance to reduce falls risk.
population_specificity: Ambulatory adults with cerebral palsy (mean age 37 years).

study_goal: The study aimed to evaluate the safety and performance of a novel direct annuloplasty system for treating functional mitral regurgitation, not Walking.
results_summary: The study found improvements in mitral regurgitation, left ventricular remodeling, and clinical outcomes, including increased 6-minute walking distance, but did not assess Walking as an independent intervention.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate to severe functional mitral regurgitation and stable heart failure medication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and efficacy of a novel intra-articular viscosupplement (HAnOX-M) with a marketed high molecular weight hyaluronic acid (Bio-HA) in alleviating knee osteoarthritis symptoms, including walking pain.
results_summary: The study found that HAnOX-M was non-inferior to Bio-HA in reducing WOMAC pain scores and improving joint function over six months, with similar safety profiles. Both treatments showed comparable efficacy in secondary endpoints like walking pain and analgesic consumption.
population_specificity: Patients with symptomatic knee osteoarthritis (OARSI grades 1-3).
effective_dosage: HAnOX-M (31mg/2ml HA + 70mg/2ml mannitol) or Bio-HA (20mg/2ml HA), administered as three intra-articular injections at weekly intervals.
study_duration: Six months (with injections given weekly for three weeks).

study_goal: To evaluate whether improvements in physical function are related to changes in body composition after a three-month progressive resistance and balance exercise program among individuals approximately one to three years after stroke.
results_summary: The intervention group showed reduced fat mass and improved walking capacity (measured by the six-minute walk test) compared to the control group. Reduced fat mass was associated with improved walking capacity in the intervention group.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling individuals aged 65-85 years, approximately one to three years post-stroke (73% men).
effective_dosage: Progressive resistance and balance exercise program twice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss mechanisms involved in Parkinson's disease (PD), neuroprotective strategies, and therapeutic approaches, including those in clinical trials or preclinical stages.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Walking's effects, as it focuses on PD pathology, mechanisms, and potential therapeutic strategies.
population_specificity: The abstract does not specify a studied population related to Walking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the baseline characteristics and treatment response (improvement in maximum walking distance) between patients with intermittent claudication included in RCTs and those receiving standard care.
results_summary: The study found that baseline characteristics were largely comparable between RCT participants and standard care patients, but improvements in maximum walking distance after three and six months were significantly and clinically less in trial participants, suggesting RCTs may underestimate the benefits of supervised exercise therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication undergoing supervised exercise therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of exercise therapy, including walking, on fatigue and other symptoms in patients with chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) compared to other interventions or controls.
results_summary: Exercise therapy, including walking, reduced fatigue and improved sleep, physical functioning, and self-perceived health in CFS patients, with no evidence of worsening outcomes. Its effectiveness was similar to cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and greater than pacing.
population_specificity: Adults with a primary diagnosis of chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS).
effective_dosage: Mixed levels of aerobic exercise intensity, including walking, swimming, cycling, or dancing; specific dosage not detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether physical prehabilitation, including walking, improves postoperative outcomes in older patients undergoing colorectal surgery.
results_summary: The studies showed no significant reduction in postoperative complications or hospital stay, but four studies reported physical improvements (e.g., walking distance, respiratory endurance) in the prehabilitation group.
population_specificity: Patients over 60 years undergoing colorectal surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare surgical outcomes in patients with lumbar canal stenosis (LCS) based on MRI morphology and assess the correlation between the Swiss Spinal Stenosis Score (SSS) and MRI morphology.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in pre-operative SSS scores, age, operative time, blood loss, symptom duration, walking distance, symptom severity, or physical function among the trefoil, triangular, and pin-hole stenosis groups. No correlation was observed between SSS scores and MRI morphology, suggesting that MRI-based stenosis type does not predict surgical outcomes at 1-year follow-up.
population_specificity: 96 consecutive patients with lumbar canal stenosis (LCS) undergoing surgery at levels L3-L4 to L5-S1.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of intermittent hypoxia (IH) combined with body weight-supported treadmill training (BWSTT) versus continuous normoxia (Nx) with BWSTT on walking performance in individuals with incomplete spinal cord injuries (iSCI).
results_summary: The study evaluated walking performance using the 10-meter walk test (10MWT), 6-minute walk test (6MWT), and timed up and go (TUG) test, but the abstract does not specify the outcomes of these comparisons.
population_specificity: American Spinal Injury Association C and D individuals with incomplete spinal cord injuries (iSCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two exercise programs (combined strength and walking vs. walking-only) on activities of daily living (ADLs) in individuals with dementia and explore potential mediators of ADL improvements.
results_summary: Both exercise programs (combined and walking-only) improved ADL levels similarly, with small but significant effects. Combined exercise showed additional benefits mediated by leg muscle strength and walking endurance, suggesting it may be more effective for targeting ADL dysfunction.
population_specificity: Individuals with dementia (mean age 85.6 ± 5.1) in psychogeriatric wards.
effective_dosage: Four 30-minute walking sessions per week (aerobic group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) in improving pulmonary function and exercise capacity in patients with acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
results_summary: The study found that TENS provided a clinically significant improvement in forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) but no significant difference compared to placebo. The placebo group showed greater improvement in six-minute walking distance, and no significant differences were observed in dyspnoea, fatigue, or quality of life scores between groups.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients with acute exacerbation of COPD.
effective_dosage: 20 sessions of TENS treatment over acupuncture points.
study_duration: Data collected between August 2013 and May 2014 (exact duration per patient not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 12-week ballistic strength-training program targeting key muscle groups for walking is more effective than usual care at improving mobility, strength, and balance in people recovering from traumatic brain injury, and whether improved mobility translates to better health-related quality of life.
results_summary: The study did not report specific results in the abstract, but it outlined a rigorous methodology to evaluate the effectiveness of ballistic strength training compared to usual physiotherapy for improving mobility and related outcomes in traumatic brain injury patients.
population_specificity: Patients with a neurologically based movement disorder affecting mobility due to traumatic brain injury, recruited during the acute phase of rehabilitation.
effective_dosage: Three 60-minute sessions per week of ballistic strength training targeting ankle plantarflexors, hip flexors, and hip extensors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if additional weekend physiotherapy and/or occupational therapy reduces rehabilitation hospital stay length and improves walking ability, daily living activities, and quality of life in stroke patients.
results_summary: Weekend therapy was associated with a shorter rehabilitation hospital stay after controlling for certain factors, but no significant improvements were found in walking speed, daily living activities, or quality of life at discharge.
population_specificity: People with stroke admitted to inpatient rehabilitation facilities.
effective_dosage: Additional weekend therapy (physiotherapy and/or occupational therapy) compared to usual care (5 days/week therapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical definition, diagnostic approach, and treatment options for camptocormia, a condition affecting walking posture.
results_summary: The study found that camptocormia has heterogeneous etiologies, requiring a broad diagnostic approach, and identified potential treatments like DBS for acute stages and orthoses for chronic stages, though no established treatment exists.
population_specificity: Patients with camptocormia, particularly those with movement disorders (e.g., Parkinson’s disease, dystonia) or muscle diseases (e.g., myositis, myopathy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and potential mechanism of action of extracorporeal shockwave therapy (ESWT) for improving walking outcomes in patients with symptomatic peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study found that ESWT significantly improved pain-free walking distance and maximum walking distance in patients with symptomatic PAD, though participant numbers were small. The mechanism of action is thought to involve mechanotransduction and subsequent angiogenesis.
population_specificity: Patients with symptomatic peripheral arterial disease (PAD).

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of virtual reality (VR) interventions for improving balance in chronic stroke patients (≥6 months post-stroke).
results_summary: VR interventions showed significant improvements in balance compared to conventional rehabilitation, as measured by the Berg Balance Scale (BBS) and the Timed Up and Go test (TUG). The meta-analysis included 20 studies, with notable effectiveness linked to Nintendo-based VR interventions.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients (≥6 months post-stroke).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if an 8-week caregiver-mediated exercise program with tele-rehabilitation could improve mobility in stroke patients and reduce caregiver burden compared to usual care.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in patient mobility but noted reduced caregiver fatigue and increased caregiver self-efficacy. Per-protocol analysis showed trends toward improved patient mobility, shorter hospital stays, fewer readmissions, and better extended activities of daily living.
population_specificity: Hospitalized stroke patients (mean age 68.7, 64% female) and their caregivers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the construct validity, responsiveness, and interpretability of the Dynamic weight-bearing Assessment of Pain (DAP) for knee osteoarthritis (OA) compared to other established measures.
results_summary: The DAP showed divergent validity with other knee OA instruments but did not fully support convergent validity with the 6MWTpain. DAP change-scores aligned with patient-reported pain changes, and a clinically relevant change was identified as 2.4 DAP points.
population_specificity: 100 participants with knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of spinal orthoses on gait and energy consumption in individuals with adolescent idiopathic scoliosis (AIS).
results_summary: The study found that spinal orthoses improved hip and pelvis movement symmetry and reduced gait asymmetry but did not decrease excessive energy expenditure during walking. Walking speed and cadence decreased, while stride length increased with orthotic use.
population_specificity: Adolescents with idiopathic scoliosis (AIS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the relationship between fatigue and exercise capacity (measured by walking tests) in sarcoidosis patients and determine if exercise test results could predict fatigue levels.
results_summary: The study found a weak correlation between exercise capacity (6MWD and SRT) and fatigue, with only 11% of fatigue variance explained by these factors. Fatigue was not significantly linked to lung function, inflammatory markers, or other clinical parameters.
population_specificity: 146 sarcoidosis outpatients referred to a Dutch ILD care foundation.
study_duration: Retrospective data collected from November 2012 to September 2014 (no specific intervention duration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the midterm outcomes of total knee arthroplasty (TKA) performed with computer navigation versus conventional techniques, focusing on implant alignment, functional scores, and implant survival.
results_summary: The computer-navigated TKA group showed statistically significant better Knee Society Scores (KSS), wider range of motion (ROM), and fewer alignment outliers compared to the conventional group. No mechanical loosening or major complications were reported, with 100% implant survival at 7 years.
population_specificity: 225 patients (240 TKAs) undergoing total knee arthroplasty, randomly assigned to conventional or computer-navigated groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of locomotor training on spinal neuronal network reorganization and motor function recovery in individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: The study found that locomotor training induces functional reorganization of spinal neuronal networks, leading to improved motor function and reduced muscle cocontractions in people with SCI. The authors emphasize the need for further research to understand the physiological mechanisms underlying these improvements.
population_specificity: Individuals with clinically complete, motor complete, or motor incomplete spinal cord injury (SCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether adding physical activity equivalents (miles of walking) to calorie labels on fast food menus influenced food selection and exercise-related attitudes.
results_summary: The study found that calorie labels, with or without walking equivalents, had little effect on food ordering behavior or exercise-related outcomes, with some counterintuitive increases in calories ordered and perceptions of exercise as less enjoyable in informational conditions.
population_specificity: 643 participants in an online study, randomly assigned to labeling conditions.
study_duration: Single session (online menu ordering task and survey)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and efficacy of single versus repeated bone marrow mononuclear cell injections for improving walking-related outcomes in critical limb ischemia patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in Ankle-Brachial Index, Visual Analog Scale, pain-free walking distance, and Wagner stage, with no adverse events reported. Repeated injections showed greater improvement in pain-free walking distance by the 24th week.
population_specificity: Patients with critical limb ischemia (n = 22).
effective_dosage: Single injection (n = 11) or four injections (n = 11) of bone marrow mononuclear cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if subcortical grey matter volumes in early multiple sclerosis (MS) patients are associated with subsequent changes in disability measures, including walking performance.
results_summary: The study found significant decreases in thalamus, caudate, and putamen volumes over time, with baseline volumes of these structures predicting changes in the timed 25-ft walk test and MSFC scores. No association was found between baseline imaging and EDSS changes.
population_specificity: Relapsing MS patients within 12 months of clinical onset.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between peripheral diabetic neuropathy (PDN), walking instability, and the intensification of depression symptoms in diabetic patients.
results_summary: The study found that symptoms related to walking instability and reduced everyday activities were strong predictors of worsening depression in diabetic patients with PDN, while the relationship between neuropathic ulcers and depression remained unclear.
population_specificity: Diabetic patients with peripheral diabetic neuropathy (PDN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare gait characteristics in progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) patients with those in Parkinson's disease (PD) patients and healthy controls to identify distinguishing features.
results_summary: Both PSP and PD patients exhibited similar hypokinetic gait traits, such as reduced velocity and step length, but PSP patients uniquely showed lower vertical displacement and higher acceleration at the same cadence compared to PD patients.
population_specificity: 20 PSP patients, 124 PD patients, and 24 healthy age-matched controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of culturally appropriate behavioral interventions, including walking, on cardiovascular disease risk factors among at-risk Latinos.
results_summary: One study reported significant reductions in systolic blood pressure and increased physical activity, while another noted cholesterol reductions. Two studies showed no significant effects on LDL, HDL, or BMI.
population_specificity: At-risk Latinos (≥1 CVD risk factor, samples >30% Latino)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how osteoarthritis (OA) in the hip, knee, or ankle affects walking velocity, energy recovery, and center of mass movements compared to asymptomatic individuals.
results_summary: Individuals with OA walked slower than asymptomatic individuals, with ankle OA showing the greatest reduction in speed. Energy recovery was lower in OA groups, particularly in hip and ankle OA, and differences were largely explained by congruity of energy fluctuations.
population_specificity: Patients with end-stage lower extremity OA (hip, knee, or ankle) scheduled for joint replacement surgery and asymptomatic individuals.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study analyzed natural walking mechanics, not a supplement).
study_duration: Single testing session within 4 weeks before joint replacement surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility, safety, and initial clinical outcomes of autologous thymosin β4 (Tβ4) pre-treated endothelial progenitor cell (EPC) transplantation in patients with acute ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), including its effects on exercise capacity (measured via 6-min walking test).
results_summary: The study found that Tβ4-pre-treated EPC transplantation significantly improved 6-min walking distance (75.7 m increase vs. 38.2 m in controls) and cardiac function in STEMI patients after 6 months, with no severe complications reported.
population_specificity: Ten patients with acute ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), randomized into control (n=5) and experimental (n=5) groups.
effective_dosage: Not specified (EPCs were pre-treated with Tβ4 24 hours before transplantation).

study_goal: To examine the effects of strength-training interventions on muscle strength and functional outcomes for adults with cerebral palsy using the ICF framework.
results_summary: Positive gains in muscle strength were reported, but changes in functional outcomes (e.g., walking speed) were inconsistent. The small sample size and lack of extended training regimens limited conclusive results.
population_specificity: Adults (mean age 18+ years) with cerebral palsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical applicability of electrical stimulation (ES) for improving functional impairments, including walking, in youth with disabilities.
results_summary: The study found that electrical stimulation may improve walking speed and foot/ankle kinematics during walking, particularly in children with cerebral palsy. Adverse reactions to ES were rare, suggesting it is safe and well-tolerated.
population_specificity: Children with various disabilities, primarily cerebral palsy.

study_goal: The abstract does not mention Zinc or its effects.
results_summary: The abstract does not discuss Zinc or its effects.
population_specificity: Patients treated with VEGFR-TKIs (vascular endothelial growth factor receptor-tyrosine kinase inhibitors).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effect of zinc status, deficiency, or supplementation on soil-transmitted helminth (STH) infection or reinfection in children.
results_summary: The review found that children infected with STH generally had lower zinc levels, but only a few studies examined zinc supplementation, with inconsistent results on its effect on STH risk.
population_specificity: Children affected by soil-transmitted helminth infections.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential effects of zinc supplementation on cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The study found that zinc supplementation has therapeutic effects on CVD risk factors, including dyslipidemia, hyperglycemia, and inflammation, which are major contributors to CVD pathogenesis in T2DM patients. The systematic review of RCTs supports these findings.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of 12 weeks of Zinc supplementation on inflammatory markers, cognitive function, and mood in overweight or obese women.
results_summary: Zinc supplementation improved cognitive scores (MMSE and Stroop tests) and increased salivary IL-1β and Zn levels, but did not significantly affect mood (BDI-II and BECK scores) or weight loss.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese women aged 40-60 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prevalence of zinc deficiency in White cancer patients and evaluate the effectiveness of zinc supplementation in correcting deficiency.
results_summary: Zinc deficiency was found in 68% of patients, with poor nutritional status and low body mass significantly associated. Oral zinc supplementation normalized plasma levels in only 27% of deficient patients, regardless of dosage (10-30 mg).
population_specificity: White patients diagnosed with neoplastic disease admitted to an oncology hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of zinc supplementation on metabolic profiles in Tanzanian infants aged 6 weeks and 6 months.
results_summary: Zinc supplementation affected various metabolites linked to amino acid, lipid, nucleotide, and xenobiotic metabolism, but the overall metabolomic changes were limited compared to the significant changes observed due to infant age. The clinical benefits of zinc supplementation were noted, but the metabolic impact was modest.
population_specificity: Tanzanian infants aged 6 weeks and 6 months.
study_duration: From 6 weeks to 6 months of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of daily zinc supplementation on thyroid auto-antibodies and oxidative stress in children with autoimmune thyroid disease compared to standard therapy.
results_summary: Zinc supplementation did not significantly affect thyroid function tests, auto-antibody titers, or oxidative stress markers. However, the zinc group did not require an increase in levothyroxine dose, unlike the control group.
population_specificity: Children aged 3-18 years with autoimmune thyroid disease (AITD), predominantly hypothyroid, with some associated comorbidities like type 1 diabetes and systemic lupus erythematosus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if high-dose zinc supplementation in very low birth weight (VLBW) infants reduces feeding intolerance, mortality, and morbidities like necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) and late-onset sepsis (LOS).
results_summary: High-dose zinc supplementation significantly reduced feeding intolerance (47.4% vs. 65.3% in controls), NEC, and LOS episodes in VLBW infants, supporting its efficacy and safety.
population_specificity: Very low birth weight (VLBW) preterm infants with gestational age <32 weeks.
effective_dosage: 9 mg + 3 mg (total 12 mg) daily, alongside regular low-dose supplementation (3 mg).
study_duration: From the seventh day of life until discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore zinc deficiency and assess the therapeutic value and safety of zinc supplementation in pediatric gastrointestinal diseases.
results_summary: Zinc supplementation reduces the duration of diarrhea in children with acute or persistent diarrhea and appears beneficial in peptic ulcer disease and gastroesophageal reflux disease, though specific guidelines for IBD and celiac disease are lacking.
population_specificity: Children with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), celiac disease, and those on long-term proton pump inhibitor treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of Zinc in cancer, including its regulatory proteins, potential as biomarkers, and therapeutic applications.
results_summary: The study found that Zinc-related proteins (ZIP and ZnT) are dysregulated in cancer and can serve as diagnostic or prognostic biomarkers. Targeting Zinc pathways or using Zinc-based therapies (e.g., supplementation or nanoparticles) shows potential for improving cancer treatment outcomes.
population_specificity: Cancer patients and cellular processes (not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of zinc supplementation on lipid profiles (LDL, HDL, TG, TC) in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: Zinc supplementation significantly improved all four lipid profile components, reducing TC, LDL, and TG while increasing HDL. The effects were statistically significant and clinically meaningful.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM)
study_duration: Varied, with significant effects observed in studies lasting <12 weeks

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of oral zinc sulfate in reducing serum bilirubin levels and the duration of phototherapy in term neonates with hyperbilirubinemia.
results_summary: Oral zinc sulfate supplementation (5 mg/day) significantly reduced total serum bilirubin levels at 24, 48, 72, and 96 hours compared to placebo, and decreased the duration of phototherapy. No significant difference in hospital stay was observed between the groups.
population_specificity: Term neonates with jaundice within the phototherapy range admitted to a level III neonatal intensive care unit.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effect of zinc supplementation on anthropometric parameters (height, weight, height-for-age) in healthy children over 2 years old.
results_summary: Zinc supplementation significantly increased height, weight, and height-for-age (HAZ) in healthy children, with pooled results showing statistically meaningful improvements. Meta-regression analysis found no significant association between dose/duration and outcomes.
population_specificity: Healthy children over 2 years old (n=1586 across 8 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of daily preventive zinc tablets and zinc-containing micronutrient powder on IGF1 and IGFBP3 levels and their effects on growth metrics (LAZ and WAZ) in young children.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in IGF1 or IGFBP3 levels from zinc supplementation, but baseline IGF1 and IGFBP3 modified the impact of zinc on growth, suggesting IGF1 bioavailability may influence catch-up growth in supplemented children.
population_specificity: Laotian children aged 6-23 months
effective_dosage: 7 mg daily (PZ) or 10 mg zinc as part of a micronutrient powder (MNP)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether zinc sulfate supplementation effectively reduces dysmenorrhoea severity in high school students.
results_summary: Zinc sulfate significantly reduced pain scores in the second and third menstrual cycles compared to placebo, with no significant differences in nausea, vomiting, or additional analgesic use. No adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: 103 high school students (52 in treatment, 51 in control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of zinc supplementation in improving postdischarge outcomes, including anthropometry and morbidity, among children treated for acute malnutrition.
results_summary: Zinc supplementation was associated with improvements in postdischarge anthropometry and reductions in multiple postdischarge morbidities. However, the evidence was limited to a single study.
population_specificity: Children aged 0 to 59 months treated for acute malnutrition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of zinc supplementation on oxidative status and glycaemic parameters in overweight patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: Zinc supplementation significantly reduced oxidative stress markers (lipid peroxidation, nitrotyrosine, total oxidant status) and increased total antioxidant capacity in T2DM patients. It also improved glycaemic control, including fasting blood glucose, insulin, haemoglobin A1c, and insulin resistance.
population_specificity: Overweight patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (n=70).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of Zinc (Zn) deficiency in CKD and hypertension progression and evaluate Zn supplementation as a potential intervention.
results_summary: The study suggests that Zn deficiency may accelerate hypertension and kidney damage in CKD, and Zn supplementation could potentially mitigate these effects.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic kidney disease (CKD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of zinc in regulating neuroinflammation and synaptic zinc homeostasis in the brain.
results_summary: The study found that proper zinc supplementation improves immunity and inhibits neuroinflammation under synaptic zinc homeostasis, while synaptic zinc homeostasis disorder promotes neuroinflammation. Cerebral ischemia and hypoxia trigger synaptic zinc release, exacerbating neuroinflammation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human physiology context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of zinc supplementation in treating taste disorders, particularly in aging populations, and assess its clinical evidence and approval status in Japan.
results_summary: Zinc supplementation is a standard treatment for taste disorders in Japan, particularly for cases linked to zinc deficiency or idiopathic causes, though clinical evidence is considered low-level. Off-label use of polaprezinc and zinc acetate hydrate has been approved, facilitating oral zinc therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with taste disorders, particularly elderly individuals in Japan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review zinc's roles in cell proliferation, survival/death, DNA repair mechanisms, and its therapeutic potential in chronic human diseases.
results_summary: Zinc modulates key cell signaling pathways, including proliferation, apoptosis, and antioxidant defenses, and its dysregulation is implicated in diseases like cancer, diabetes, and Alzheimer's. The study highlights zinc's therapeutic potential but does not provide specific clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: General human physiology and chronic disease contexts (not a specific study population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential link between zinc deficiency and hand-foot skin reaction (HFSR) development, as well as whether zinc supplementation could alleviate HFSR symptoms.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that zinc deficiency may contribute to HFSR development and that zinc supplementation might relieve symptoms, but no large-scale clinical studies confirm this. The evidence is based on case reports and series.
population_specificity: Patients experiencing HFSR due to multikinase inhibitors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily zinc supplementation could prevent severe or invasive infections in young Ugandan children with sickle cell anemia (SCA).
results_summary: Zinc supplementation (10 mg daily) did not reduce the incidence of severe or invasive infections compared to placebo. However, a post-hoc analysis suggested a potential reduction in stroke or death in the zinc group, though many children remained zinc-deficient despite supplementation.
population_specificity: Ugandan children aged 1.00-4.99 years with sickle cell anemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether zinc acetate supplementation was safe and effective for improving outcomes in patients with acute myocardial infarction (AMI) after primary percutaneous coronary intervention.
results_summary: The study found no significant reduction in major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE) between the zinc supplementation and conventional treatment groups. However, scar size (% core zone) was numerically lower in the zinc group, though not statistically significant (P=0.07).
population_specificity: Patients with AMI who underwent successful primary percutaneous coronary intervention.
study_duration: Zinc supplementation was administered within 24 hours post-intervention, with outcomes assessed at 4 weeks after discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between serum zinc levels, inflammatory markers, and the severity of COVID-19 infection.
results_summary: The study found that COVID-19 patients had significantly lower serum zinc levels compared to healthy controls, with a negative correlation between zinc levels and disease severity. Inflammatory markers were positively correlated with disease severity and negatively correlated with zinc levels.
population_specificity: 123 COVID-19-positive adult patients and 48 healthy controls, categorized into mild, moderate, and severe infection groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if zinc supplementation reduces relapse probability and improves mental health in opioid use disorder patients undergoing methadone maintenance treatment.
results_summary: Zinc supplementation significantly reduced drug use likelihood, cravings, and relapse prediction scores, while also improving depression, anxiety, and stress levels compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 68 patients with opioid use disorder receiving methadone maintenance treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antiviral effect of zinc supplementation in COVID-19 patients and assess its impact on mortality and adverse events.
results_summary: Zinc supplementation was associated with lower in-hospital mortality (21.6% vs. 23.04%) and reduced 28-30 day mortality (7.7% vs. 11.9%). No significant differences in adverse events (e.g., acute kidney injury, need for mechanical ventilation) were observed between zinc-treated and non-treated patients.
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether zinc supplementation was associated with COVID-19–associated mucormycosis (CAM) in patients treated for COVID-19.
results_summary: The study found zinc supplementation significantly associated with CAM (OR 2.76, 95% CI 2.24–3.40), suggesting a potential adverse effect rather than therapeutic benefit in this context.
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients across 25 hospitals in India, including 1,733 CAM cases and 3,911 age-matched controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of zinc supplementation in improving the rate of weight restoration in patients with anorexia nervosa.
results_summary: Zinc supplementation was associated with a doubled rate of body mass index increase compared to placebo, indicating a significant positive effect on weight restoration in AN patients.
population_specificity: Inpatients with anorexia nervosa aged 16 years and older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between zinc deficiency and taste change after bariatric surgery and assess the effectiveness of zinc supplementation in improving taste perception.
results_summary: The study found that taste change and zinc deficiency are common after bariatric surgery, typically occurring around 6 months post-surgery. Supplementation with 45-50 mg of zinc sulphate was effective in improving taste, though no direct causal link between zinc deficiency and taste change was established.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficacy of oral zinc supplementation in reducing mortality, ICU admissions, and symptom duration in adult patients with COVID-19.
results_summary: Zinc supplementation reduced 30-day mortality (6.5% vs. 9.2%), ICU admissions (5.2% vs. 11.3%), and shortened hospital stays (by 3.5 days) and symptom duration (by 1.9 days) compared to placebo, with no severe adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Adult patients with COVID-19 infection, both ambulatory (40.4%) and hospitalized (59.6%), without end-organ failure.

study_goal: The researchers were investigating gene therapy approaches for inherited retinal diseases, not Zinc.
results_summary: The abstract discusses gene therapy trials for inherited retinal diseases but does not mention Zinc or its effects.
population_specificity: Patients with inherited retinal diseases (autosomal recessive, X-linked, and autosomal dominant conditions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate zinc's potential as a preventive and adjunct therapy for COVID-19, focusing on its immune and antiviral functions.
results_summary: Zinc deficiency was associated with increased COVID-19 susceptibility and severity, while supplementation showed potential protective effects by enhancing immunity, reducing susceptibility, shortening illness duration, and decreasing disease severity.
population_specificity: High-risk groups for zinc deficiency and COVID-19 patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between semen parameters (potentially influenced by zinc supplementation) and live birth rates among couples seeking infertility treatment.
results_summary: Lower quartiles of semen parameters (e.g., morphology, motility, concentration) were associated with fewer live births in couples undergoing ovulation induction (OI) or intrauterine insemination (IUI), while only low morphology was significant for in vitro fertilization (IVF). The study suggests semen quality, potentially modifiable by zinc, plays a critical role in fertility outcomes.
population_specificity: Couples (n = 2,369) seeking fertility consultations at four US infertility care centers.
study_duration: Semen parameters assessed at baseline and at 2, 4, and 6 months after enrollment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the impact of different zinc supplementation regimens on antibody production against pathogenic Escherichia coli in Laotian children with zinc deficiency.
results_summary: Zinc supplementation (7, 10, or 20 mg/day) significantly increased anti-E. coli IgG levels, particularly in zinc-deficient children, with preventive zinc tablets (PZ) showing the best improvement in both antibody quantity and quality. The control and PZ groups also exhibited increased antibody avidity.
population_specificity: Laotian children aged 6-23 months, many with zinc deficiency (78.5%) and anemia (40%).
effective_dosage: 7, 10, or 20 mg/day elemental zinc (therapeutic dispersible tablets, daily micronutrient powder, or preventive zinc tablets).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the molecular mechanisms of zinc's role in immune response modulation and its potential as a preventive and therapeutic agent for infectious diseases.
results_summary: Zinc deficiency is linked to immune disorders and infectious diseases, while zinc supplementation shows anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties, potentially aiding immune defense. The study highlights zinc's role in modulating pro-/anti-inflammatory responses but notes gaps in comprehensive understanding.
population_specificity: Vulnerable populations, including the elderly in Western countries and children in developing countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of zinc in the progression of periodontitis and periodontal regeneration, focusing on its regulatory effects during immune defense, inflammatory response, and bone remodeling.
results_summary: The study found that zinc plays a key role in immune defense, inflammatory response, and bone remodeling during periodontitis. Zinc supplementation or regulation of zinc transport proteins can promote periodontal regeneration by enhancing immune defense and up-regulating cell proliferation and differentiation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on periodontal health)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify risk factors, including zinc supplementation, associated with COVID-19-associated Mucormycosis (CAM).
results_summary: The study found that 84.6% of CAM patients were prescribed zinc preparations, suggesting a potential association between zinc use and mucormycosis risk, though causality was not established.
population_specificity: Patients admitted with mucormycosis (primarily rhino-orbital-cerebral) between May 2021 and July 2021 in India, most with diabetes and recent COVID-19 infection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the causal effect of Zinc supplementation alone on glycemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D).
results_summary: Zinc supplementation significantly reduced fasting blood glucose, HbA1c, and HOMA-IR in T2D patients. Mendelian randomization also supported a causal reduction in fasting glucose levels.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether zinc supplementation via SQ-LNS or dispersible tablets affects fat-free mass (FFM) and fat mass (FM) deposition in young children.
results_summary: The study found that SQ-LNS with morbidity treatment increased weight gain and FFM without increasing FM deposition. Additional zinc supplementation did not significantly affect changes in FFM or %FM.
population_specificity: Young children aged 9 to 18 months from 34 communities.
effective_dosage: 0, 5, or 10 mg zinc incorporated in SQ-LNS or 5 mg zinc as dispersible tablets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of zinc supplementation on COVID-19 mortality through a meta-analysis of existing studies.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that zinc supplementation significantly reduced mortality risk in COVID-19 patients, with a pooled odds ratio of 0.57 (95% CI: 0.43–0.77, P < 0.001). The results suggest zinc may be a cost-effective intervention for lowering mortality in COVID-19 cases.
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients (1,506 participants across five studies).
